Rainfall Estimates from Rain Gauge and Satellite Observations
Published

August 30, 2024

  • Overview

About the data

The Climate Hazards Center InfraRed Precipitation with Station data (CHIRPS), was explicitly designed to provide blended gauge-satellite precipitation estimates that cover most global land regions, have a fairly low latency, high spatial resolution, low bias, and a long period of record. CHIRPS version 2 is a 40+ year quasi-global (50°S-50°N), land-only, gridded dataset available at 0.05° and 0.25° degree resolutions. It is created by integrating multiple data sources, including satellite imagery at 0.05° resolution and in-situ station data, to generate rainfall time series for trend analysis and seasonal drought monitoring. The dataset begins in 1981 and extends to the near-present day.

For more information regarding CHIRPS datasets see CHIRPS-website or CHIRPS FAQ.

Summary

Name CHIRPS-2.0
Institution CHC
Product type gridded observed
Domain global land (50°S-50°N), africa land
Resolution 0.05° x 0.05°, 0.25° x 0.25°
Period 1981-2024
Frequencies daily, pentad, dekad, monthly, 2-monthly, 3-monthly, annual
Variables precipitation
Update frequency (latency) monthly (+- 1 month)

Variables

Variable Name Variable Description Units
precip convective precipitation rate millimetres per day

Strengths and limitations

Strengths

The dataset has high spatial and temporal resolution. It provides a relatively long and continuous record (1981-present) It has a relatively rapid update frequency (latency)

Limitations

It only provides rainfall and does not include other key variables required for malaria modelling.

Notes for users

As is the case with most gridded climate datasets, the CHIRPS dataset provides its time variable in Coordinated Universal Time (UTC). If one is working in a time zone far from the UTC line, you may need to adjust the time variable to align with your local time zone when interpreting daily totals or other time-sensitive data. Southern Africa is typically UTC+2, meaning a daily rainfall total in CHIRPS data which is 12AM to 12AM UTC, would reflect rainfall from 2 AM to 2 AM local time.

Accessing the data

Guidance and metadata

Via Climate Data Guide: CHIRPS: Climate Hazards InfraRed Precipitation with Station data (version 2)

Via Climate Data Store: Temperature and precipitation gridded data for global and regional domains derived from in-situ and satellite observations

Data download

Via The Climate Hazard Centre (CHC) at the University of California, Santa Barbara CHIRPS v2.0. The following data is available for the entire period (1981 to 2024):

Domain Frequency Resolution File Format
africa daily 0.05, 0.25 .tif, .bil
africa pentad, dekad, monthly 0.05 .tif, .bil, .png
africa, global 2-monthly, 3-monthly 0.05 .tif
global daily 0.05, 0.25 .tif, .nc, .cog
global dekad 0.05 .tif, .bil, .nc
global pentad, monthly 0.05 .tif, .bil, .nc, .cog
global annual 0.05 .tif, .nc

Via Climate Data Store: Temperature and precipitation gridded data for global and regional domains derived from in-situ and satellite observations. The following data is available for the period (1981 to 2021):

Domain Frequency Resolution File Format
africa daily 0.25 .nc

Terms of use

Citation

Funk, C., Peterson, P., Landsfeld, M. et al. The climate hazards infrared precipitation with stations—a new environmental record for monitoring extremes. Sci Data 2, 150066 (2015). https://doi.org/10.1038/sdata.2015.66
